SpectraPepper Documentation

Introduction

Introduction¶

SpectraPepper is a Python package that makes advanced analysis of spectroscopic data easy and accessible through straightforward, simple, and intuitive code. This library contains functions for every stage of spectroscopic methodologies, including data acquisition, pre-processing, processing, and analysis. In particular, advanced and high statistic methods are intended to facilitate, namely combinatorial analysis and machine learning, allowing also fast and automated traditional methods.

Features¶

The following is a short list of some of the main procedures that SpectraPepper package enables.

  • Automatic and user-defined baseline removal.
  • Several normalization methods.
  • Noise filters, trimming, and other pre-processing tools.
  • Combinatorial analysis tools, including Spearman, Pearson, and n-dimensional correlation coefficients.
  • Tools for Machine Learning applications, such as data merging, randomization, and decision map.
  • Easy export of data to text files to use visualization software, such as Origin.

Quickstart¶

  1. Install this library using pip:

    pip install spectrapepper

  2. Install this library using conda-forge:

    conda install -c conda-forge spectrapepper

  3. Test it by printing the logo!:

    import spectrapepper as spep
spep.logo()

Functions¶

This main module that contains all the functions, since this package is function-based for simplicity. Keep in mind that some of this functions are only meant to be used inside this file, however they all might be useful in other code. asdasd

my_functions.areacalculator(x_data, limits, norm=False)¶

Area calculator using the data (x_data) and the limits in position, not values.

Parameters:
  • x_data (list[float]) – Data to calculate area from
  • limits (list[int]) – Limits that define the areas to be calculated.
  • norm (bool) – If True, normalized the area to the sum under all the curve.
Returns:

A list of areas according to the requested limits.
Return type:

list[float]
my_functions.avg(data)¶

Calculates the average vector from a list of vectors.

Parameters:data (list[(]float]) – List of vectors.
Returns:The average of the vectors in the list.
Return type:list[float]
my_functions.baseline_als(y, lam=100, p=0.001, niter=10)¶

Calculation of the baseline using Asymmetric Least Squares Smoothing. This script only makes the calculation but it does not remove it. Original idea of this algorythm by P. Eilers and H. Boelens (2005), and available details at: https://stackoverflow.com/a/29185844/2898619

Parameters:
  • y (list[float]) – Specra to calculate the baseline from.
  • lam (int) – Lambda, smoothness. The default is 100.
  • p (float) – Asymetry. The default is 0.001.
  • niter (int) – Niter. The default is 10.
Returns:

Returns the calculated baseline.
Return type:

list[float]
my_functions.bincombs(n, s_min=1, s_max=0)¶

Returns all possible unique combinations.

Parameters:
  • n (int) – Amount of positions.
  • s_min (int) – Minimum amount of 1s.
  • s_max (int) – Maximum amount of 1s.
Returns:

List of unique combinations.
Return type:

list[tuple]
my_functions.bspbaseline(data, x_axis, points, avg=5, remove=False)¶

Calcuates the baseline using b-spline. Find useful details and guidelines in https://stackoverflow.com/a/34807513/2898619.

Parameters:
  • data (list[float]) – Single vector.
  • x_axis (list[float]) – x axis of the data, to interpolate the baseline function.
  • n – positions in axis of points to calculate the bspine.
  • avg (bool) – points to each side to make average.
  • avg – if True, calculates and returns (data - baseline).
Returns:

The baseline.
Return type:

list[float]
my_functions.butter_lowpass_filter(data, cutoff=0.25, fs=30, order=2, nyq=0.75)¶

Butter low pass filter for a single or spectra or a list of them.

Parameters:
  • data (list[float]) – List of vectors in line format (each line is a vector).
  • cutoff (float) – Desired cutoff frequency of the filter. The default is 0.25.
  • fs (int) – Sample rate in Hz . The default is 30.
  • order (int) – Sin wave can be approx represented as quadratic. The default is 2.
  • nyq (float) – Nyquist frequency, 0.75*fs is a good value to start. The default is 0.75*30.
Returns:

Filtered data
Return type:

list[float]
my_functions.classify(data, gnumber=3, glimits=[])¶

Classifies targets according to either defined limits or number of groups. The latter depends on the defined parameters.

Parameters:
  • data (list[float]) – Vector with target values to be classified.
  • gnumber (int) – Number of groups to create. The default is 3 and is the default technique.
  • glimits (list[float]) – Defined group limits. The default is [].
Returns:

Vector with the classification from 0 to N. A list with strings with the name of the groups, useful for plotting.
Return type:

list[list,list]
my_functions.cmscore(x_points, y_points, target)¶

Calculates the distance between points and the center of mass (CM) of clusters and sets the prediction to the closest CM. This score may be higher or lower than the algorithm score.

Parameters:
  • x_points (list[float]) – Coordinates of x-axis.
  • y_points (list[float]) – Coordinates of y-axis.
  • target (list[int]) – Targets of each point.
Returns:

Score by comparing CM distances. Prediction using CM distances. X-axis coords of ths CMs. Y-axis coords of the Cms.
Return type:

list[float, list[int],list[float],list[float]]
my_functions.colormap(c, name='my_name', n=100)¶

Just to simplify a bit the creation of colormaps.

Parameters:
  • c (list) – List of colors thaat you ant on the colormap
  • name (string, optional) – Name of the colormap. The default is ‘my_name’.
  • n (TYPE, optional) – Divisions. The default is 100.
Returns:

Colormap in Matplotlib format.
Return type:

cmap
my_functions.confusionmatrix(tt, tp, gn, plot=False, groupnames=['', '', '', ''], title='', colormap='Blues')¶

Calculates and/or plots the confusion matrix for machine learning algorithm results.

Parameters:
  • tt (list[float]) – Real targets.
  • tp (list[float]) – Predicted targets.
  • gn (int) – Number of classification groups.
Returns:

The confusion matrix
Return type:

list[float]
my_functions.cortopos(vals, ax)¶

To translate values to a position in an axis, basically searching for the position of avalue. Normally they dont fit perfectly, so it is useful to use this tool that aproximates to the closest.

Parameters:
  • vals (list[float]) – List of values to be searched and translated.
  • ax (list[float]) – Axis.
Returns:

Position in the axis of the values in vals
Return type:

list[int]
my_functions.decbound(xx, yy, xlims, ylims, divs=0.01)¶

Calculates the Decision Boundaries.

Parameters:
  • xx (list[float]) – X coordinates of centroids.
  • yy (list[float]) – Y coordinates of centroids.
  • xlims (list[float]) – Limits.
  • ylims (list[float]) – Limits.
  • divs (float) – Resolution. The default is 0.01.
Returns:

The decision boundaries.
Return type:

list[float]
my_functions.decdensity(lims, x_points, y_points, groups, divs=0.5)¶

Calculates the density decision map from a cluster mapping.

Parameters:
  • lims (list[float]) – Plot and calculation limits.
  • x_points (list[float]) – X coordinates of each point.
  • y_points (list[float]) – Y coordinates of each point.
  • groups (list[int]) – List of targets for each point.
  • divs (float) – Resolution ti calculate density. The default is 0.5.
Returns:

The density decision map.
Return type:

list[float]
my_functions.gaussian_fit(data_x, ax, sigma=4.4, it=100)¶

Fit a Gaussian distributed curve for a single spectra. Good guidelines for similar structures can be found at http://emilygraceripka.com/blog/16.

Parameters:
  • data_x (list[float]) – single spectra.
  • ax (list[float]) – x-axis.
  • sigma (float) – sigma parameter of distribution. The default is 4.4.
  • it (int) – number of iterations. The default is 100.
Returns:

Gaussian fit.
Return type:

list[float]
my_functions.grau(data)¶

This function evaluates the MSE in 3 dimensions (x,y,z) for a set of data vectors.

Parameters:data (list[float]) – A list of lists (no typo) of variables to compare.
Returns:A list with each combination and the R2 score obtained.
Return type:list[float]
my_functions.groupscores(all_targets, used_targets, predicted_targets)¶

Calculates the individual scores for a ML algorithm (i.e.: LDA, PCA, etc).

Parameters:
  • all_targets (list[int]) – List of all real targets (making sure all groups are here).
  • used_targets (list[int]) – Targets to score on.
  • predicted_targets (list[int]) – Prediction of used_targets.
Returns:

List of scores for each group.
Return type:

list[float]
my_functions.interpolation(data, x_axis)¶

Returns an array with the first item being the interpolated data and the second item being the axis.

Parameters:
  • data (list[float]) – data to interpolate
  • x_axis (list[float]) – axis of data
Returns:

Interpolated data and the new axis
Return type:

list[list[float],list[float]]
my_functions.isaxis(data)¶

Detects if there is an axis in the data.

Parameters:data (list[float]) – Data containing spectras an possible axis.
Returns:True if there is axis.
Return type:bool
my_functions.load_data(file)¶

Load data from a standard text file obtained from LabSpec and other spectroscopy instruments. When single measurement these come in columns with the first one being the x-axis. When it is a mapping, the first row is the x-axis and the following are the measurements. Sometimes the first 2 columns will be the coordinates. No headers, yet.

Parameters:file (str) – Url of data file. Must not have headers and separated by ‘spaces’ (LabSpec).
Returns:List of the data.
Return type:list[float]
my_functions.logo(lay=90, leng=100, a=1, b=0.8, r1=80, r2=120, lw=2)¶

Prints the logo of SpectraPepper.

Parameters:
  • lay (int) – Amount of layers/vectors. The default is 90.
  • leng (int) – Length of the layers. The default is 100.
  • a (int) – Amplitud. The default is 1.
  • b (int) – Width. The default is 0.8.
  • r1 (int) – Random lower limit. The default is 80.
  • r2 (int) – Random upper limit. The default is 120.
  • lw (int) – Line width. The default is 2.
my_functions.lorentzian_fit(data_x, ax, wid=4, it=100)¶

Fit a Lorentz distributed curve for a single spectra. Good guidelines for similar structures can be found at http://emilygraceripka.com/blog/16.

Parameters:
  • data_x (TYPE) – single spectra.
  • ax (TYPE) – x-axis.
  • wid (TYPE, optional) – fitted curve width. The default is 4.
  • it (TYPE, optional) – number of iterations. The default is 100.
Returns:

Lorentz fit.
Return type:

list[float]
my_functions.mdscore(x_points, y_points, target)¶

Calculates the distance between points and the median center (MD) of clusters and sets the prediction to the closest MD. This score may be higher or lower than the algorithm score.

Parameters:
  • x_points (list[float]) – Coordinates of x-axis.
  • y_points (list[float]) – Coordinates of y-axis.
  • target (list[int]) – Targets of each point.
Returns:

Score by comparing MD distances. Prediction using MD distances. X-axis coords of ths CMs. Y-axis coords of the Cms.
Return type:

list[float, list[int],list[float],list[float]]
my_functions.mergedata(data)¶

Merges data, it can merge large vectors. Useful to merge features before performing ML algorithms.

Parameters:data (list[list[float]]) – List of arrays.
Returns:List with the merged data.
Return type:list[float]
my_functions.moveavg(move, data)¶

Calculate the moving average of a single or multiple vectors.

Parameters:
  • move (int) – Average range to each side (total average = move + 1).
  • data (list[float]) – Data to calculate the moving averge. Single or multiple vectors.
Returns:

Smoothed vector(s).
Return type:

list[float]
my_functions.no_baseline(data, lam=100000, p=0.001, niter=10)¶

This takes baseline_als and removes it from the spectra.

Parameters:
  • data (list[float]) – list of spectras
  • lam (int) – also known as lambda, smoothness
  • p (float) – asymetry
  • niter (int) – niter
Returns:

The spectra with the removed als baseline.
Return type:

list[float]
my_functions.normsum(data)¶

Normalizes the sum under the curve to 1, for single or multiple spectras.

Parameters:data (list[float]) – Single spectra or a list of them.
Returns:Normalized data
Return type:list[float]
my_functions.normtoglobalmax(data)¶

Normalizes a list of spectras to the global max.

Parameters:data (list[float]) – List of spectras.
Returns:Normalized data
Return type:list[float]
my_functions.normtomax(data)¶

Normalizes spectras to the maximum value of each, in other words, the maximum value of each spectras is set to 1.

Parameters:data (list[float]) – Single or multiple vectors to normalize.
Returns:Normalized data.
Return type:list[float]
my_functions.normtopeak(data, x_axis, peak, shift=10)¶

Normalizes the spectras to a particular peak.

Parameters:
  • data (list[float]) – Data to be normalized, no x-axis
  • x_axis (list[float]) – X-axis of the data
  • peak (int) – Peak position in x-axis values.
  • shift (int) – Range to look for the real peak. The default is 10.
Returns:

Normalized data.
Return type:

list[float]
my_functions.normtovalue(data, val)¶

Normalizes the spectras to a set value, in other words, the define value will be reescaled to 1 in all the spectras.

Parameters:
  • data (list[float]) – Single or multiple vectors to normalize.
  • val (float) – Value to normalize to.
Returns:

Normalized data.
Return type:

list[float]
my_functions.peakfinder(data, l=10)¶

Find the location of the peaks in a single vector.

Parameters:
  • data (list[float]) – Data to find a peak in.
  • l (int) – Amount of position to each side to decide if it is a local maximum. The default is 10.
Returns:

A vector of same length with 1 or 0 if it finds or not a peak in that position
Return type:

list[int]
my_functions.peakfit(data, ax, pos, look=20, shift=5, wid=5)¶

Feats peak as an optimization problem.

Parameters:
  • data (list[float]) – Data to fit. Single vector.
  • ax (list[float]) – x axis.
  • pos (int) – Peak position to fit to.
  • look (int) – positions to look to each side. The default is 20.
  • shift (int) – Possible shift of the peak. The default is 5.
Returns:

Fitted curve.
Return type:

list[float]
my_functions.plotgrau(data, labels, cm='seismic', fons=20, figs=(25, 15), tfs=25, ti='Grau (Beta)', marker='s', marks=100)¶

Performs Grau correlation matrix and plots it.

Parameters:
  • data (list[float]) – Data to be correlated.
  • labels (list[str]) – Labels of the data to be ploted.
  • cm (str) – Color map for the plot, from matplotlib. The default is “seismic”.
  • fons (int, optional) – Plot font size. The default is 20.
  • figs (tuple) – Figure size. The default is (25,15).
  • tfs (int) – Plot title font size. The default is 25.
  • ti (str) – Plot title. The default is “Grau (Beta)”.
  • marker (str) – Plot marker type (scatter). The default is “s”.
  • marks (int) – DESCRIPTION. The default is 100.
my_functions.plotpearson(data, labels, cm='seismic', fons=20, figs=(20, 17), tfs=25, ti='Pearson')¶

Calculates Pearson matrix and plots it.

Parameters:
  • data (list[float]) – Data to correlate.
  • labels (list[str]) – Labels of the data.
  • cm (str) – Color map as for matplolib. The default is “seismic”.
  • fons (int) – Plot font size. The default is 20.
  • figs (tuple) – Plot size. The default is (20,17).
  • tfs (int) – Title font size. The default is 25.
  • ti (str) – Plot title/name. The default is “spearman”.
my_functions.plotspearman(data, labels, cm='seismic', fons=20, figs=(20, 17), tfs=25, ti='Spearman')¶

Calculates Pearson matrix and plots it.

Parameters:
  • data (list[float]) – Data to correlate.
  • labels (list[str]) – Labels of the data.
  • cm (str) – Color map as for matplolib. The default is “seismic”.
  • fons (int) – Plot font size. The default is 20.
  • figs (tuple) – Plot size. The default is (20,17).
  • tfs (int) – Title font size. The default is 25.
  • ti (str) – Plot title/name. The default is “spearman”.
my_functions.regression(target, variable, cov=0, exp=0)¶

Performs an N dimensional regression.

Parameters:
  • target (list[float]) – Y-axis values, values to predict.
  • variable (list[float]) – X-axis values.
  • cov (int) – If 1 is regression with covariance, like spearman. The default is 0.
  • exp (int) – For exponent (non linear) regressions. Not working yet. The default is 0.
Returns:

Prediction of the fitting and the Fitting parameters.
Return type:

list[list[float],list[float]]
my_functions.sdev(data)¶

Calculates the standard deviation for each bin from a list of vectors.

Parameters:data (list[(]float]) – List of vectors.
Returns:Standard deviation curve
Return type:list[(]float]
my_functions.shiftref(data, peak_ref=520, mode=1, it=100, plot=True)¶

Shifts the x-axis according to a shift calculated prior.

Parameters:
  • data (list[float]) – Reference measurement (Si), with axis.
  • peak_ref (float) – Where the reference peak should be in x-axis values. The default is 520 (Raman Si).
  • mode (int) – Fitting method, Lorentz, Gaussian, or none (1,2,3). The default is 1.
  • it (int) – Fitting iterations. The default is 100.
  • plot (bool) – If True plots a visual aid. The default is True.
Returns:

Shift amount
Return type:

float
my_functions.shuffle(arrays, delratio=0)¶

Merges and shuffles data and then separates it so it is shuffles together.

Parameters:
  • arrays (list[list[float]]) – List of arrays of data.
  • delratio (float) – Ratio of the data to be deleted, 0 < delratio < 1
Returns:

List of the shuffled arrays.
Return type:

list[list[float]]
my_functions.subtractref(data, ref, alpha=0.9, sample=0, plot=True, plot_lim=[50, 200], mcr=False)¶

Subtracts a reference spectra (i.e.: air) from the measurements.

Parameters:
  • data (list[float]) – List of spectras, with x-axis.
  • ref (list[float]) – air (reference) data, with x-axis.
  • alpha (float) – Manual multiplier. The default is 0.9.
  • sample (int) – Sample spectra to work with. The default is 0.
  • plot (bool) – To plot or not a visual aid. The default is True.
  • plot_lim (list[int]) – Limits of the plot.
  • mcr (bool) – Use MCR (self calculation), not available yet. The default is False.
Returns:

Data with the subtracted reference.
Return type:

list`[float]
my_functions.trim(data, start=0, finish=0)¶

Deletes columns in a list from start to finish.

Parameters:
  • data (list) – Data to be trimmed. Single vector at the moment.
  • start (int, optional) – Poistion of the starting point. The default is 0.
  • finish (int, optional) – Position of the ending point. The default is 0.
Returns:

Trimmed data.
Return type:

list[]
